prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: The Panel has, in limited circumstances, ordered remand of part of a transferred action. Partial remand can occur in two circumstances: upon initial transfer or following pretrial proceedings in the transferee court.

Remand is available to the Panel if it feels transfer under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 is appropriate for portions of certain actions, but does not feel the actions should be transferred in their entirety. The statute specifically allows remand in this circumstance.[1] For example, in one case the Panel ordered transfer and coordination of pretrial proceedings in a number of cases pending from two separate merger transactions. The Panel determined that transfer was justified because of common factual issues relating to the use of the same financial information in the two transactions. The Panel did not transfer, but remanded to the transferor district, a counterclaim against individual plaintiffs in one of the mergers. The Panel found no common issues as to that counterclaim.[2] The Panel may separate any claim and remand it rather than transfer it.[3]
The Panel's power to sever and remand a portion of an action is limited to entire claims. It may not remand only part of a claim or only certain factual issues.[4]

The Panel exercises the power to sever and transfer some claims while remanding others quite sparingly. The Panel will not sever and remand portions of the claims unless there are few, if any, common factual issues.[5] In Midwest Milk the Panel stated:

The Panel is empowered by statute to couple its order of transfer with a simultaneous separation and remand of any claims in an action. See 28 U.S.C. § 1407(a). Before we exercise that power, however, we must be convinced that the claims to be returned to the transferor court have little or no factual overlap with the claims to be transferred.[6]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
28 U.S.C.A. § 1407(a). The statute is reprinted in § 3:19.
In re Boise Cascade Securities Litigation, 364 F. Supp. 459, 461 (J.P.M.L. 1973).

In re Aviation Products Liability Litigation, 347 F. Supp. 1401 (J.P.M.L. 1972); In re Antibiotic Drugs, 309 F. Supp. 155, 157 (J.P.M.L. 1970) (Clayton Act and fraud on Patent Office claims transferred, patent cancellation claim left in court in which filed).

See, e.g., In re Resource Exploration, Inc., Securities Litigation, 483 F. Supp. 817 (J.P.M.L. 1980); In re Air Crash Disaster at Greater Cincinnati Airport on November 20, 1967, 298 F. Supp. 353 (J.P.M.L. 1968) (Panel refused to sever damage issue from liability and remand damage issues to transferor districts).
In re 1980 Decennial Census Adjustment Litigation, 506 F. Supp. 648, 650 (J.P.M.L. 1981); In re Midwest Milk Monopolization Litigation, 386 F. Supp. 1401, 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
